document.text: Youth Week will be observed in Liberty Church August 26-Sept- ember 2. James Whitehead will ser ve as Youth Pastor and Catherine Richardson as Youth Music pir- ector. The Young People of the church will assume the leadership of the various departments, classes, and organizations of the Church, as - assigned by the Youth Advisby ory Committee. The week will be climaxed by a week-end of Activities directed by a visiting Youth Team. Members of the team are David Sandridge, University of Richmond student Page Carmean, graduate of Blue- field College and Wayne Barber, student of Bluefield College. The schedule for the week-end of August 31-September 2 will be as follows Friday, Aug. 31 Supper 600 at parsonage Visitation Recreation Saturday, Sept. 1 Youth Forum 730 SingspiTation Fellowship Sunday, Sept. 2 Worship 1100 David Sandridge. leading. All Young People in the Inter mediate and Young Peoples De partment are urged to be presenv for all activities.

document.text: Williamsburg.- Virginias Fourth Estate celebrates 715 years of or ganization when the Virginia Press Association holds its Diamond An niversary Convention here Thurs- day, Friday and Saturday, Ju ly 18, 19-20. More than 300 Virginia newspapermen and women, their families and invited guests will participate in the gathering. Highlight of the convention will be the Parks-Franklin memorial ob servance in tribute to Virginias colonial printer and Americas first Public Printer. Working in coopera tion with the Colleg of William and Mary and the Virginia 350th Anniversary Celebration, the V . P. A . will hold a dinner on Ju ly 19, following which wili be the presen tation of an award to the Ameri can adjudged the outstanding champion of freedom of informa tion and the never-ending battle for the peoples right to know. Nominations for the recipient of the award have been received from throughout the United States. Pre sentation will be held in Phi Beta Kappa hall. The recipient, whose name has not been disclosed, will be present ed a solid silver miniature of n_ colonial press. The press, fashioned of five .pounds ocf silver, was de signed and executed by William de- Mjaltte, Colonial Williamsburg silver smith who made the Freedom Bell presented to Sir Winston Churchill T8 months ago in recognition of his championship of freedom. Cost of the silver press minia ture was borne by most of the daily and weekly newspapers in Virginia. Speaker at the dinner will be Raymond Blattenberger, United States public printer and head of the government printing office in Washington, and Don Whitehead, chief of the Washington Bureau of the Nhw York Herald Tribune, and former Associated Press corespon dent who won two Pulitzer prizes for distinguished reporting. Miss Marguerite Osborne, Edi tor of The -Virginia Gazette, is chairman of the V . P. A . Awards Committee, Ralph K . T . Larson, managing editor of the Norfolk Virginian-Pilot and a member of the award committee, will preside at the dinner. The invocation will be given by the Rev. Cotes worth Lewis, rector of old Bruton Parish Church in Williamsburg. Alvin D. Chandler, president of the College of William and Mary, will deliver the address of welcome.

document.text: William Clement, colored, made an assault on Mr. George Rosser, of Campbell last week, and fractured his jawbone. The negro was lodged in jail. Sunday night, about midnight a howling mob from Burtons creek came upon the jailer and aroused him, sayiug that Constable Whitehead, of Concord had a prisoner for com mitment. The keys were demanded of the jailer at the point of pistols. He refused to give up the keys,but the mob rushed in and took the prisoner out, and he was shot four times dur ing the scuffle aud a great many masks were pulled off. The negro was not lynched is still alive and after escaping the mob was recap tured and lodged in jail. It is said he recognized several of the men and wan ants will be sworn out against them.

document.text: When the Red Cross Bloodmobile makes its third of five visits for this fiscal year to Appomattox a ruesday, Eveivn Crain, Patricia Butler Harry Hamlett and Mike Shafer,,fqr Mood-Honors--v  avwer, ask you to join them idgqjdl unit oi your iitosaying Blood. The Bloodmobile will set up from noon until 6 p.m. Tuesday at Liberty Baptist Church and the quota for this visit is set at 102 units of blood. A nursery will be provided for children of Mood donors and all seventeen year olds are reminded that they may donate blood with parental Consent. You may secure consent forms, if needed, from Mrs. Lucy Harvey. Xi Gamma Tau, Exemplar of Beta Sigma Phi Sorority will be in charg eof the canteen at this visit. The Appomattox Junior Womans Club is the sponsoring organization with Mrs. Mary Catherine Whitehead as their representative. Rev. Earnie Lucas is Chairman of the Blood Program in our county and is assisted by Mrs. Lucy Harvey. These people have done an excellent job in past years and with the continued assistance of our most important people - the donors - we will continue to keep Appomattox County 100 of its quota. document.text: Weed KUler Allowing livestock to graze liberal ly on plants sprayed with the weed killer, 2,4D, may be risky, accord ing to a new scientific report. Al though moderate amounts of 2,4-D are not poisonous to livestock, it is believed that this chemical can bring about an increase in the ni trate content of plants. Nitrates are changed to a poisonous substance in the rumen of cattle and sheep, causing illness and death through a complex process that blocks the transfer of oxygen from the lungs to body tissues. A number of cat- tie became ill or died after eating pigweed, ragweed, Jimson weed, and similar plants sprayed with 2.4D, workers at the South Dakota experiment station observed. They then made tests which revealed that leaves of beets had a deadly concentration of nitrate after ac cidental spraying with 2,4-D, while unsprayed leaves contained a rela tively harmless amount. The inves- uo5is k- M. Stahler and E I Whitehead, urged stockmen to get an immediate diagnosis if illness or death occurs after cattle and sheep feed on sprayed plants

document.text: W. R. Kennedy Defeats Mayor Walk er At Lexington By Three Votes. Lexington, Va. Special.At the municipal election held in Lexington Tuesday, William R. Kennedy was elected mayor over the Incumbent Samuel B. Walker by a majority of three votes. All of the present coun oilmen were re-elected. There were 108 votes polled and four thrown out as defective. Capt. Walker has senr ed two terms. This Is Mr. Kennedy first political office. . Herndon, Va. Special.  The wwn election at this place Tuesday resulted as follows Councilmen E. L. Robey, H. B. Hutchinson, F F. Russell, F. E. Reed, C. M. Bur ton, E. Dyer, and E. N. Fitzhugh clerk, M. T. Wilkins sergeant, E W. Bauchman. The result of the election is considered as favorable to Mr. Ryans candidacy for Con gress. Luray, Va. Special.In a hotly contested election for town officials here Tuesday, T. A. Smoot, a mem her of the Luray bar, defeated Thom as R. Campbell, who has been mayor for six years, by a majority of tw votes. The following ticket was elected For councilmen, John H Booton, C. G. Mason, R. T. Morrl son, and J. F. McNeally, all being new, except Councilman Booton. Chatham, Va. Special.In the municipal election here J. H. Har grave, Jr., was re-elected mayor over L. P. Clyde, by thirty-eight majority W. M. Whithead, J. W. Whitehead B. S. White, W. B. Shepherd, E. S Reid, and A. D. Bennett were elected councilmen.

document.text: Uurtaville. Well this is the 22nd day of April, 1911. Wintev has taken leave of ns, and ia unmbered with the past. March ended with bright, and crisp weather. The budding of the trees, chirp of little ohicks, and planting gardena reminda na that gentle Spring ia here. There has been qnite a lot of siokneas in this vicinity of late, but they all are improving soma. Mrs. J. A Jennings ia very much indisposed at this writing. Mr. Robert Gilliam, one of onr highly esteemed citisens and neigh bors, still continues to improve, and we hope for him a speedy reoovery. Mrs. J. R. Hughes, who haa been sick with la gripp , ia improving, and we are glad to see her out. again The Hurtaville School, tanght by Mias Hattie A. Drinkard, closed on the 30th of March, and surely pat ron and pupil can well say  well done good and faithful servant. Miss Hattie was liked and gave satis faction to both patron and pupil and her departure leaves many tad hearts and faces behind, bat we hope it will not be long before she will be in oar midst again, and that she will be with ns again next fall Our little Sunday School at St. Pauls is getting on very niosly, and we have very good attendance and we think as Summer approaches w will have a very flourishing and in teresting school. Miss Carrie Jennings, who is at tending the Farmville State Nor mal, spent Easter with her parents near Hurtaville. Rev. T. H. Lacy, we are glad to say, will be with ns April 30th and also May 1st. He will be accom panied by Bishop Tucker. We are al ways glad to have Dr. Laoy with us. He is a fine preacher and a good man. Mr. Jas. P. Walker,, who has been visiting at his wifes mothers, Mrs. 8. B. Hurt, returned home last Thursday. 1 think all the farmers around Hurtaville have finished selling to bacco, and some received satisfac tory prices. Wonder if the farm ers will ever awake to the fact that it would be better to raise more of everything to eat and less tobaoco. Every year they bow a few oats, plant a small area,in corn, neglect their gardens and concentrate all theiT energies on a big tobacco orop and then have to buy everything to eat for both man and beast. Why not try to raise everything to eat, and then what tobacco they can ? Mr. J. R. Whitehead, who spent the winter at his old home here, is on a visit now to friends and rela tives. The F. E.  G. U. of A. meets on Saturday afternoon at Hnrtsvilie and so far they seem to be progress ing very nicely. Why dont all of yoj farmers.come in and work to gether?

document.text: Twenty - one seniors have been named Honor Students by Ap pomattox High School, as they close out twelve years of study in commencement exercises scheduled for June 5. About ten of the twenty - one have college plans with the remainder plann ing on business, nursing, or homemaking careers. Top Four Principal Frank C h uc h e k stresses the fact that scholarship is important, but that exact rating as far as grades are concerned is a difficult thing to determine. He pointed out that all of the top four graduates, Marlene Barger, Joan Moses Gaynell Thompson, and Suzanne Gills, have had very good grades and made real achievement in their school careers thus far. Only a hair - line separates them Insofar as rank in the class is concerned, he said, and we think of our graduates as people not numbers. Senior Events The Junior - Senior prom will be held tomorrow night, Friday, at the gymnasium. Baccalaure ate Service will be held at Lib erty Baptist Church June 2, with Rev. O. D. Moore delivering the address. A Senior Banquet is be ing planned, as well as Class Day, with Commencement exer cises in the school auditorium the evening ef June 5. Whitehead having this 10th day of June appearead before me, the Judge of CircuU Court for Ap pomattox county and presented a petition and application praying1 that he be appointed as administra tor for one Mattie Whitehead, pre sumed to be dead, which said peti tion and application is hereby ord ered to be filed in the clerks of fice of Appomattox County, Vir ginia. And it appearing to the court that Mattie Whitehead resided in Appomattox county and that she w nt therefrom and has not been heard from or returned to the coun ty of Appomattox, Virginia, nerto the state of Virginia for the past seven years successively and has not been heard of since she left, and the court being satisfied that the appli cant, J. B. Whitehead, would be en titled to administer upon the estate of the said Mattie Whitehead if she were in fact dead, it is therefore ordered that notice of the said -,eti- tion and application of the said J. B. Whitehead shall be published once a week for four successive weeks in the Times Virginian, a newspaper published in the county of Appomattox, Virginia, and that no tice be given that on the 19th day of July, 1941 at ten oclock A. A miscellaneous shower was given in iier honor by Mrs. La than Har vey and Mrs. Millard Harvey, in the Social Hall of liberty Baptist Church at 8 P.M. January 7 . The refreshment table was centered with a decorated wedding cake and the bridal motif was carried out in the decorations.- The bride was the re cipient of jnony lovely, useful gifts from the large number of friends present. The grooms mother, Mrs. Guy Ferguson, of Altavista, was among those present. Also assist ing the hostesses were Mesdhmes L. E. Conner, J. A. Conner and J. B. Whitehead.. On January 8, the choir of Liber ty Baptist Church, of which Miss Mitchell is a member, entertained Fore fr her and her fiance at a coffee  hour at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Jamerson. A most impressive and beautiful candlelight service, the Y. W. A. Bible presentation, Was given in honor of Miss Mitchell on Wednes day night, January 11, at the church.  Following the wedding rehearsal Friday night, January 13, the grooms parents, Mr. and Mrs.. Guy Ferguson entertained at Mauds Restaurant for the entire wedding party.

document.text: This week the emphasis is on- youth, as the largest youth organi zation in the worldthe 4-H Clubs observe National 4-H Achieve ment Week, with November 13 set aside as National 4-H Achievement Day. Members number two million, of which some 60,000 are in the state of Virginia. Around 500 boys and girls are enrolled in 20 4-H Clubs in Appomattox County. The 4-H Clubs of Appomattox County will observe Achievement Day Saturday, November 13, having their annual meeting at the Lee Theater at 130 P. M., through the courtesy of Mr. J. C. Caldwell. Sammy Ferguson, chairman of Appomattox County 4-H Council, will preside over the meeting. The program will include reports on special trips, project accomplish ments and entertainment by . club members. The management of Lee Theater will show a movie. Awards for outstanding accomplishments will he presented to a number of 4-H Club members by Mrs. B. G. Anderson, home agent, and by Mr. Whitehead, assistant county agent. Almost without exception, the boy or girl who makes.., the most progress in 4-H Club work is the one who has the active interest of his or her parents. 4-H Club lead ers also play an important part in the progress of the club members. Appreciation is expressed for the help they give. All club members, their parents and friends are invited to attend the annual Achievement Day pro gram -Saturday,. November 13, at 130 P. M. at the Lee Theater.

document.text: This lad is our present postmaster, John Kent Hamilton. In the spring of 1917 came the cry of war. So far as we cen deter mine, six former pupils of the Ever green school served with the A. E. F. in World War I. The first draft call from Appomattox County was for eight men, who entrained for Camp Lee on Sept. 6, 1917,, headed by Frank P. Glover, of Evergreen.! In 1922, Evergreen school secur ed Misses Lois Whitehead and Lucie Butler as teachers, the latter being fresh from Farmville Normal. Lucie taught here one year and elsewhere four others, then came back to our community as Mrs. Lucie Staples wife of one of our charter pupils Henry Staples. In 1944, 22 years after her first teaching, she again assumed responsibilities as principal of our school and continues as such. In the Evergreen school house on January 31, 1928, the Evergreen Community League was organized with J. L. Staples, pres. J. P. Paul ett, v. pres. Elsie Marks, secy. and treas.
